Code of Ethics for Journalists
The Code of Ethics is a self-regulating instrument which aims to guide
column2: strengthen and improve the quality of journalism and the sense of responsibility of journalists in Albania.

column1: The principles of this Code are in line with the universal ethical values of journalism
column2: which are widely recognized and accepted by media organizations and journalism unions in democratic countries. They are a cornerstone of democratic pluralism and also respect the spirit of the Constitution of the Republic of Albania
column3: the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights.

column2: freedom of information and criticism
column3: freedom of the press
column4: and access to official documents are basic elements of a democratic society.

column1: Media play an extraordinarily important role in society
column2: by providing reliable and timely news and information in various forms and through assorted platforms. The media serve as watchdogs
column3: holding centers of power to account and constantly monitoring government authorities and organizations
column4: institutions and businesses. Media play a fundamental role in the democratic processes and provide ample opportunities and a safe environment to allow journalists to perform their duties independently.

column1: The media recognize the importance of pluralism in society and respect the diversity of opinions
column2: opposing all discrimination based on sex
column3: race
column4: nationality
column5: language

column1: The media recognize and defend both its rights and duties versus the public
column2: constantly preserving the balance between them.

column1: The following regulations concerning conduct shall apply to all persons and organizations engaging in the gathering
column2: editing
column3: preparation and dissemination of journalistic information. The scope of the Code shall cover the individual and collective supply of information performed in the field of printed (text and photography) and electronic media.

column1: The Code refers to individual and collective responsibilities in the supply of information performed in the field of printed (text and photography) and electronic media.
The principles of this Code apply equally to all media and journalistic platforms
column2: offline and online
column3: including journalism disseminated through social media and internet portals.

column1: The Code of Ethics presumes and expects that all media organizations and journalists recognize and accept the voluntary principles set out in this Code. All those who engage in journalism are invited to acknowledge and accept the following principles as necessary to the well-being of journalism and freedom of expression in Albania.
Journalists who knowingly violate the principles of this code betray the trust of the public and may not expect the support and solidarity of their colleagues
column2: media organizations or journalism trade unions. Controversies arising from alleged violations of the Code are dealt with through transparent systems of voluntary self-regulation developed by journalists and news media organizations that may operate at the level of the enterprise and across different platforms of the news media industry.

column1: Journalists have the right to seek information and the right of access to public information. They have the right to publish and to criticize.
Journalists and news media shall at all times strive to publish information that is to the best of their knowledge truthful
column2: balanced and verified.

column1: A journalist must verify information prior to its publication in order to ensure that it is accurate
column2: fact-based and trustworthy. All data and information must be subject to careful scrutiny: whether it is obtained from human sources or documents.

column1: Journalists should always indicate where information has not been confirmed.
Media should not mislead the public. They should clearly indicate where manipulated texts
column2: documents
column3: images and sounds have been used.

column2: image
column3: audio
column4: or visual arrangements that distort the ideas or facts of the source
column5: with the exception of caricatures

column1: Journalists shall strive to provide unbiased and balanced reporting. Journalists shall refer to all available sources and interested parties that can provide useful and relevant information.

column2: journalists should be inclusive and seek to ensure that all parties concerned have an opportunity to state their position.

column1: Criticized parties shall have the right to respond to accusations
column2: whenever possible in the same publication. Journalists shall make every effort to contact all sides and gather all relevant opinions. Mere contacts with both sides do not “release' a journalist from the obligation to present both sides of a story
column3: and to report as truthfully as possible.

column1: The principle of “presenting all sides' may not apply in publications representing personal opinions (editorials
column2: opinion pieces) as well as reports of a factual nature
column3: such as reporting on public meetings or events.

column1: Media must distinguish clearly between opinion and comments and fact-based reporting. Columnist
column2: caricaturists
column3: and critics are allowed to present their opinions on individuals and events. News relates to information supported by facts and data
column4: while an opinion piece contains and represents ideas
column5: opinions and considerations of journalists

column1: Media shall be open to engage with their audience and to deal with legitimate comments and complaints.

Media should publish a clear and appropriately prominent correction when it can be demonstrated that inaccurate or misleading information has been published. Media should provide an apology and appropriate remedy where it is necessary.
A criticized party shall always have the right of response.
If the reply is not fit for publication as such
column2: changes to it should be discussed with the writer. If he or she cannot be contacted within a reasonable time
column3: the reply may be published in amended form. However
column4: its essential contents must not be changed.

column1: Journalists shall strive to gather information from all available sources in order to provide accurate
column2: complete
column3: and impartial information.

column1: Journalists shall be transparent in their work and use methods for gathering information that are ethical and lawful.
A person being interviewed has the right to know in which medium and in what connection statements will be used.
Journalists shall exercise care in the selection of sources and establish clear working relations with them to make sure that the information they receive is correct.
Media shall exercise particular care in dealing with sources who are members of vulnerable groups
column2: such as children and young people
column3: victims of violence or minorities.

column1: Media shall not distort or misuse statements made in a specific context. In particular consideration should be shown towards people who cannot be expected to be aware of the effect that their statements may have.
Journalists shall not divulge the name of a person when information is provided on a confidential basis
column2: unless consent has been explicitly given by the person concerned.

column1: The right to the anonymity may be broken only if:
a) There is suspicion that the source consciously has distorted truth or is seeking to manipulate media for personal gain;
b) The reference to the name of the source is the only way to avoid serious and inevitable damage to others;
c) The information in question relates to the planning of a serious criminal act or is of major concern for public welfare.
If unjustly denied access to requested information
column2: a journalist has the right to inform the general public about it.

column1: Media shall avoid unacceptable conflicts of interest and shall not permit any undue influence arising from personal beliefs
column2: political or financial incentives to affect the accurate and impartial reporting of their journalists and work of editorial departments.
publishers
column3: and media owners must resist threats
column4: provocations
column5: or incentives to influence
column6: distort or conceal information. They shall not use any information or data collected during their job for their own personal benefit.

column1: Editorial content should be clearly distinguished from marketing
column2: advertisements
column3: materials prepared by political parties or other institutions/organizations
column4: or sponsored content. Sponsored content must clearly show the identity of the sponsor.

column2: as well as sponsored content – including articles and supplements – shall be labeled accordingly to ensure the media audience can distinguish them from editorial content.

column1: Journalists who agree not to publish a piece of information or material for a given period of time must respect these arrangements. Such an agreement (embargo) should be considered null and void if the information is published by another party
column2: or when the person who requested the embargo in any way violates terms and conditions of the agreement reached between parties.

column1: In the interests of fairness and accuracy journalists may show their news stories to interested parties prior to publication
column2: but they shall not grant a veto on the right to publish and shall be free to decide for themselves on what suggestions they should take under consideration.

column1: The publisher and editor are liable and responsible for the publication of news articles as well as letters to the editor
column2: comments and replies published on the media website including where the name of the author is omitted or signed under an alias.

column1: Media and editorial staff should agree to and publish clearly defined terms and conditions for the selection and publishing of comments from the public. Media shall monitor and review such comments and take steps to ensure the terms and conditions of publication are respected.
Media have the right to add a “note' on comments and replies
column2: or even decide not to publish them at all
column3: with the exception of cases when it has previously promised to publish such comments. The editorial staff reserves the right to edit or shorten letters to the editor
column4: or comments

column1: Media must not publish materials that incites intense hatred or violence towards individuals based on race
column2: religion

column1: Media and journalists shall respect the honor and reputation of individuals who become objects of their professional interest.
Any incorrect or false information that intentionally or unintentionally may cause harm to the image and reputation of another person constitutes a breach of human dignity.

A journalist must respect the right of an individual to privacy. Only the protection of the public interest can justify journalistic investigations which interfere with the private aspects of the lives of individuals. Journalists shall only make reference to personal or private aspects of people's lives when they are relevant.
Journalists will use fair methods in the collection of information. They only make use of subterfuge
column2: hidden cameras
column3: microphones or other special equipment
column4: or obscure their professional identity
column5: in circumstances where:

column1: a) There is no other means to obtain the information concerned
b) The information is of urgent and serious concern to the public
Journalists shall indicate when such methods have been used in the story or provide disclosure when circumstances permit.
“Sudden' use of cameras in public or institutions should respect the desire and sensitivity of the present persons.
Public figures are entitled to less privacy than other individuals. However
column2: information on their private lives and information related to their family and friends should be disclosed only when it serves the public interest. Public officers are also justified in not disclosing their private life except for the cases when their private life may affect their public activity.

editors and editorial managers must not seek personal gain from information and evidence collected by their media organization. Media organizations shall ensure that there are internal arrangements for the declaration of potential conflicts of interest at all levels of ownership
column3: management and editorial activity.

column2: editors and journalists so not have the right to use the professional information they collect during the course of their work for any other purpose than to inform the public.

column1: Journalists should avoid covering stories where they have a direct personal interest.
The taking of bribes or inducement of any kind in order to alter or affect their reporting
column2: or failure to publish a piece of information
column3: shall be considered by journalists as a serious breach of professional ethics.

column2: violence
column3: outrage or malicious information intended to injure the feelings of the whole public or parts of it is unethical and unacceptable in any media product.

column1: Violence and brutality shall not be sensationalized. Reporting must take due account of the need to protect minors and vulnerable groups in society
Journalists and media shall not glorify crimes and terrorism or any other cruel and inhuman activities.
Media shall report with care and sensitivity issues of crime and violence and shall treat with caution the identification of victims and witnesses of crime. In cases involving sexual assault
column2: victims shall not be identified unless they willingly give consent.

column1: Journalists shall respect the dignity of victims and their families and shall allow people to grieve in private and will report such matters with sympathy and constraint.
In the case of accidents and disasters
column2: media shall bear in mind that rescue operations for victims and persons in jeopardy take precedence over the public's right to be informed.

column1: Media shall not sensationalize reporting with explicit pictures of catastrophes
column2: accidents or violence that might insult the feelings of the relatives as well as sensibilities of the public.

column1: Victims or missing persons shall not be identified if next-to-kin have not been informed.
13. Reporting of Court Proceedings and Presumption of Innocence
Reporting from the courthouse (including the publishing and broadcasting of images)
column2: should be accurate
column3: fair
column4: not prejudicial
column5: and fully respectful of the right to a fair trial.

column1: Journalists will always respect presumption of innocence and will refrain from describing someone as a criminal prior to final court conviction.
When reporting on juvenile crime and juvenile court proceedings
column2: media shall exercise restraint out of consideration for the future of the young people concerned.

column1: This recommendation also applies to reports on victims of migration and illegal human trafficking.
Media should carefully consider whether to publish facts about family scandals and historical crimes committed by individuals who have served their sentence.
14. Protection of Children and People with Limited Abilities
A journalist shall respect all principles confirmed in International Conventions on the Rights of the Child and Albanian legislation on child protection and persons with limited abilities.
A journalist protects the rights and dignity of children and people with limited abilities
column2: including their right to be heard.
there is no objection to the publication of photographs and names of missing young persons but theses shall only be published with the agreement of the relevant authorities or responsible adults.

column1: Journalists shall not take advantage of children's innocence and trust and will publish information or images about the private life of a child only if there is an overriding public interest.
Journalists shall not normally interview children under 18 on personal issues in the absence of parents or responsible persons.

column2: and will encourage colleagues to respect the copyright of others in any creative area. They shall attribute information they use to its original source. Plagiarism is inadmissible.
if they:

column1: a) Publish or attempt to publish the work of others as if it was their own (plagiarism);
b) They quote from the work of others in such a way that they distort the original meaning
column2: publishing distortion as reality
column3: or wilfully indicate another person
column4: as author;

column1: c) publish as their own a topic considered as original - researched and published by someone else - without reference to the origin;

d) hand over their work for publishing to two or more publishers at the same time - without indicating this fact - or hand over an already published work and do not draw the attention of the second publisher to this fact;
e) publish a work without the consent of the author
column2: or alter the material without permission
column3: or put it into an unworthy surrounding (composition of pictures)
column4: or a surrounding different from the previous agreement
column5: without the consent of the author.

column1: In their business relations media and journalists should recognize the importance of fair competition and professional solidarity and maintain appropriate balance between the two.
The journalist should not impede the colleagues to gather information
column2: to mislead them intentionally
column3: or report on them to the authorities.

column2: nor separate editorial staffs shall use mass media for the prosecution of personal and professional rivalries and disputes.

column1: Journalists shall respect the confidentiality of their workplace where this information is not related to violations of laws and the Code of Ethics.
Media shall respect the right of individual journalists to act according to their conscience and their right to refuse assignments
column2: or not to be identified as the author of publications
column3: which they believe are in contravention of the letter and spirit of this Code.

column1: The terms of this Code provide essential and necessary guidelines for the exercise of ethical journalism and may only be disregarded in exceptional circumstances in order to serve the public interest.
Public interest is defined in these circumstances as follows:
Matters of urgent and immediate concern to public health and safety;

column2: prevention
column3: and disclosure of serious crimes
column4: scandals
column5: and abuse of power;

column1: Actions to protect the public from the danger of being seriously misled.
Legitimate public interest does not justify sensationalism and in the spirit of this Code it should never be confused with information that is ‘'interesting to the public'.

Journalists should respect and carefully observe the rules of the Albanian language. The use of foreign words should be avoided except for clarity of meaning or when appropriate in direct reporting.

Guiding Principles for Journalistic Activities (Code of Ethics for the Austrian Press)
Journalism requires freedom and responsibility. Newspaper publishers and editors
column2: broadcasting and television managers
column3: as well as journalists have particular responsibility for maintaining the freedom of the mass media
column4: which is a vitally important element of democratic life.

column1: This is a special challenge for the heads of editorial offices
column2: who have to ensure the consistent respect of the principles that should guide the work of journalists under their authority.

column1: The Austrian Press Council (Österreichischer Presserat) is the platform for all those who support the idea that the use of the freedom of the press should be guided by the principles of truthfulness and accuracy
column2: and who are willing to submit their products
column3: in concrete cases
column4: to the scrutiny of the Press Council. Voluntary self-regulation on a permanent basis is an appropriate means to ensure that the press meets its responsibility.

column2: the Austrian Press Council has laid down the following catalogue of principles (Code of Ethics for the Austrian Press) for all those who are engaged on behalf of newspaper in the gathering
column3: dissemination and commenting of the news. This catalogue can be supplemented or interpreted by guidelines as and when needed. The principles stated below shall hold for all those parts of a publication
column4: which are under the editors' responsibility.

column1: Newspaper and magazines that commit themselves to compliance with the principles of this Code of Ethics undertake to publish every and any finding of the Austrian Press Council directed against said newspaper or magazine and the publication of which the Council has required (signet in their imprint).
The Freedom of news reporting and commenting
column2: be it in words or in pictures
column3: forms an integral part of the freedom of press. There shall be no restrictions regarding the collection and dissemination of news and comment.

column1: For the Press Council and its activities
column2: the limits to this freedom are set by the journalists' voluntary self-regulation based on the provision of this Code of Ethics.

column1: It is the prime duty of journalists to aim at a maximum of conscientiousness and accuracy in their investigations
column2: the presentation of news items
column3: and comments in them.

column1: Quotes between quotation marks shall reflect the tenor as detailed as possible
column2: and no quotation marks shall be used for passages
column3: which merely render the generic sense of a statement. Quoting from anonymous sources should be avoided unless anonymity is required in the interest of the safety of the person quoted or in order to protect such person from some other serious disadvantage.

column1: No charges shall be made against any person(s) or institution(s) unless proof can be furnished that an attempt has been made to obtain a statement on said charges form the person(s) or institution(s) so charged. If the charge in question has been made in public
column2: this circumstance shall be clearly indicated
column3: and the source of said charge shall be named.

column1: As soon as an editorial office is advised of the fact that it has published a wrong statement
column2: professional ethics and common decency demand that a correction of a said statement be published voluntarily.

column1: Any justified statement on the part of a reader or readers calling for correction of a report shall be published as soon as possible and as extensive as required.

Adequate coverage shall be given to any important court decision or finding of another public authority regarding a subject on which the newspaper or magazine has reported or to any essential new findings concerning said subject that have emerged in some other way.
Readers shall be left in no doubts as to whether a newspaper item is a factual report
column2: the reproduction of the views of a third party or third parties
column3: or comment.

column1: In case of serious doubts about the correctness of a quotation
column2: the validity of third-party statements shall be checked before said statements are reproduced.

column1: Photomontages and picture material that has been modified shall be clearly marked as such if a cursory reading might otherwise lead the reader to believe them to be documentary in nature.
Form and content of contributions to the editorial sections of a newspaper or magazine shall on no account be influenced by outside interests.

Such improper influence shall be deemed to comprise not only interventions or pressure that is brought to bear on a journalist but also the granting of personal advantages relative to matters that lie outside the immediate realm of the journalist's professional work.

column2: in the context of his/her work as a journalist
column3: presents or any other personal advantages likely to influence the journalistic product shall be deemed to have breached this Code of Ethics.

column1: The publishers' economic interests shall not affect editorial content in any way that might result in wrong information or the suppression of important information.
If a journalist publishes a report on a journey
column2: which has been paid for by a third party
column3: this fact shall be mentioned in the report in a suitable way.

column1: Every person is entitled to the protection and respect of his/her dignity and personality.
Libellous or disparaging statements about a person or persons violate the Code of Ethics.
Persons whose life is in jeopardy shall not be identified in media reports if such identification is likely to expose them to even greater danger.
Particular attention must be paid to the anonymity interests of victims of accidents or crimes. The identity of a victim may be disclosed if there is an official reason to do so
column2: if the victim is a well-known person
column3: or if the victim or close relatives have consented to the disclosure.

column1: The privacy of all individuals shall in principle be protected.

column2: protection of the individual's privacy shall take precedence over the news value.

column1: Before pictures and reports about juveniles are published
column2: special critical consideration shall be given to the question of whether such publication is in the public interest.

column1: Reports about criminal offences or misconduct on the part of juveniles shall not render more difficult or completely prevent their eventual re-integration into society. In such cases
column2: the individual's full name shall not be published.

column1: Journalists shall exercise particular caution in interviewing and photographing children and in reporting about matters which might have a detrimental influence on their future.
7. Protection from Sweeping Statements and Discrimination
Sweeping statements which disparage or incite suspicion against a person or group of persons shall be strictly avoided.

column2: disability
column3: sex

column5: religion
column8: ideology or for any other reason shall be inadmissible.

No unfair or improper methods shall be used in obtaining oral or procuring written evidence.
Unfair or improper methods shall include misrepresentation
column2: pressure
column3: intimidation
column4: exploitation of emotional or stressful situations and
column5: as a rule

Safeguarding the freedom of speech in Denmark is closely connected with the free access of the media to collect information and news and to publish it as correctly as possible. VI. LIABILITY FOR VIOLATIONS OF THE CODE OF ETHICS OF THE MEDIA
The activities of journalists that have violated the provisions of the Code of Ethics are grounds:
• for the administration of the producer of public information to apply disciplinary measures to such a journalist;
• for a trade union of journalists to expel such a journalist from the union;
• for any persons concerned to submit complaints regarding the activities of the producers and communicators of public information which have potentially violated the provisions of the Code;
• to apply any other sanctions stipulated in the laws.
The activities of a producer and/or a communicator of public information that have violated the provisions of the Code of Ethics are grounds:

• to attribute that producer and/or communicator to the category of a producer and/or communicators of public information who does not honour professional ethics in accordance with the procedure established by the Ethics Commission for Public Information;
